title: Data Input
text: MRInput object following “slots” : betaX betaXse numeric vectors describing associations genetic variants exposure. betaX beta-coefficients univariable regression analyses exposure genetic variant turn, betaXse standard errors. betaY betaYse numeric vectors describing associations genetic variants outcome. betaY beta-coefficients regression analyses outcome genetic variant turn, betaYse standard errors. correlation matrix signed correlations variants. correlation matrix provided, assumed variants uncorrelated. exposure character string giving name risk factor, e.g. LDL-cholesterol. outcome character string giving name outcome, e.g. coronary heart disease. inputs used graphing functions. snps character vector names various genetic variants (SNPs) dataset, e.g. rs12785878. necessary name exposure, outcome, SNPs, names used graphing functions may helpful keeping track various analyses.

title: Data Input
text: generate MRInput object slot slot, one can use mr_input() function : necessary slots filled. example, methods require bxse specified; example, mr_ivw function still run bxse set zeros. vectors bx, bxse, , byse equal length, error reported. Note package implement harmonization associations effect allele; must done user. also possible run analysis using syntax: However, care must taken case give vectors correct order (: bx, bxse, , byse).
code: MRInputObject <- mr_input(bx = ldlc,                            bxse = ldlcse,                            by = chdlodds,                            byse = chdloddsse)  MRInputObject  # example with uncorrelated variants ##     SNP exposure.beta exposure.se outcome.beta outcome.se ## 1 snp_1         0.026       0.004       0.0677     0.0286 ## 2 snp_2        -0.044       0.004      -0.1625     0.0300 ## 3 snp_3        -0.038       0.004      -0.1054     0.0310 ## 4 snp_4        -0.023       0.003      -0.0619     0.0243 ## 5 snp_5        -0.017       0.003      -0.0834     0.0222 ## 6 snp_6        -0.031       0.006      -0.1278     0.0667 ##  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 22 rows ] MRInputObject.cor <- mr_input(bx = calcium,                                bxse = calciumse,                                by = fastgluc,                                byse = fastglucse,                               corr = calc.rho)  MRInputObject.cor  # example with correlated variants ##     SNP exposure.beta exposure.se outcome.beta outcome.se ## 1 snp_1       0.00625     0.00233      0.02805     0.0122 ## 2 snp_2       0.00590     0.00338      0.00953     0.0198 ## 3 snp_3       0.01822     0.00318      0.03646     0.0173 ## 4 snp_4       0.00598     0.00233      0.01049     0.0119 ## 5 snp_5       0.00825     0.00229      0.02357     0.0122 ## 6 snp_6       0.00651     0.00352      0.00204     0.0179 MRInputObject <- mr_input(ldlc, ldlcse, chdlodds, chdloddsse)

title: Data Input
text: PhenoScanner bioinformatic tool (http://phenoscanner.medschl.cam.ac.uk) curated database publicly available results large-scale genetic association studies. database currently contains 65 billion associations association results 150 million unique genetic variants, mostly single nucleotide polymorphisms. PhenoScanner can called directly MendelianRandomization package using pheno_input() function. creates MRInput function, can directly used input estimation functions. example: (implement code , requires connection internet, hence produces error internet connection found. please copy try !) order obtain relevant summary estimates, run pheno_input() function : - snps character vector giving rsid identifiers genetic variants. - exposure character vector giving name risk factor. - pmidE PubMed ID paper association estimates exposure first published. - ancestryE ancestry participants association estimates exposure estimated. (traits PubMed IDs, results given multiple ancestries.) Usually, ancestry “European” “Mixed”. - outcome character vector giving name outcome. - pmidO PubMed ID paper association estimates outcome first published. - ancestryO ancestry participants association estimates exposure estimated. note spelling exposure outcome, PubMed ID, ancestry information need correspond exactly values PhenoScanner dataset. spelled exactly PhenoScanner dataset (including upper/lower case), association estimates found.
code: mr_ivw(pheno_input(snps=c("rs12916", "rs2479409",                            "rs217434", "rs1367117",                           "rs4299376", "rs629301",                           "rs4420638", "rs6511720"),                    exposure = "Low density lipoprotein",                    pmidE = "24097068",                     ancestryE = "European",                    outcome = "Coronary artery disease",                    pmidO = "26343387",                    ancestryO = "Mixed"))

title: Data Input
text: Two sets data provided part package: ldlc, ldlcse, hdlc, hdlcse, trig, trigse, chdlodds, chdloddsse: associations (beta-coefficients standard errors) 28 genetic variants LDL-cholesterol, HDL-cholesterol, triglycerides, coronary heart disease (CHD) risk (associations CHD risk log odds ratios) taken Waterworth et al (2011) “Genetic variants influencing circulating lipid levels risk coronary artery disease”, doi: 10.1161/atvbaha.109.201020. calcium, calciumse, fastgluc, fastglucse: associations (beta-coefficients standard errors) 7 genetic variants CASR gene region. 7 variants correlated, correlation matrix provided calc.rho. data analysed Burgess et al (2015) “Using published data Mendelian randomization: blueprint efficient identification causal risk factors”, doi: 10.1007/s10654-015-0011-z.

title: Graphical summaries of results
text: mr_plot function two different functionalities. First, function applied MRInput object, output interactive graph can used explore associations different genetic variants look outliers, may represent pleiotropic variants. syntax : interactive graph reproduce well vignette, encourage readers input code . interactive graph allows user pinpoint outliers easily; user mouses one points, name variant shown. option error = TRUE plots error bars (95% confidence intervals) associations exposure outcome. option orientate = TRUE sets associations exposure positive, re-orientates associations outcome needed. option encouraged MR-Egger method (otherwise points negative associations exposure can appear far regression line), although default set FALSE. line option can set “ivw” (show inverse-variance weighted estimate) “egger” (show MR-Egger estimate). static version graph also available, setting interactive = FALSE:  version graph less useful detecting outliers, easier save file share colleagues. Outliers can identified using labels = TRUE option:  resulting graph quite ugly, easy identify individual points.
code: mr_plot(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse, by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse),  error = TRUE, orientate = FALSE, line = "ivw") mr_plot(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse, by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse),  error = TRUE, orientate = FALSE, line = "ivw", interactive = FALSE) mr_plot(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse, by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse),  error = TRUE, orientate = FALSE, line = "ivw", interactive = FALSE, labels = TRUE)

title: Graphical summaries of results
text: mr_plot command can also applied MRMVInput object created using mr_mvinput() function. case, horizontal axis present associations single exposure, fitted value multivariable IVW method, representing expected genetic association outcome based genetic associations exposures.
code: MVMRInputObject <- mr_mvinput(bx = cbind(ldlc, hdlc, trig),                               bxse = cbind(ldlcse, hdlcse, trigse),                               by = chdlodds,                                byse = chdloddsse)  mr_plot(MVMRInputObject, interactive = FALSE)

title: Graphical summaries of results
text: Finally, mr_plot function applied output mr_allmethods function, estimates different methods can compared graphically.    see estimates methods similar LDL-cholesterol risk factor, MR-Egger estimates differ substantially HDL-cholesterol risk factor.
code: MRInputObject <- mr_input(bx = ldlc,                            bxse = ldlcse,                            by = chdlodds,                            byse = chdloddsse) #put data into MR input format MRAllObject_all <- mr_allmethods(MRInputObject, method = "all") #apply all MR methods   mr_plot(MRAllObject_all) # create plot MRAllObject_egger <- mr_allmethods(MRInputObject, method = "egger") mr_plot(MRAllObject_egger) mr_plot(mr_allmethods(mr_input(bx = hdlc, bxse = hdlcse,   by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse)))

title: Graphical summaries of results
text: graphical functions mr_forest command, can either provide forest plot variant-specific estimates:  comparison various estimates different methods:  mr_funnel command, provides funnel plot variant-specific estimates precision (, reciprocal standard error):  (Note plot first 8 variants ) mr_loo command, provides leave-one-estimates - , estimate based variants except variant 1, based variants except variant 2, .  plots ggplot objects, can edited using commands ggplot2 package. example, set x-axis run -5 +5:
code: mr_forest(MRInputObject, ordered=TRUE) mr_forest(MRInputObject,           methods = c("ivw", "median", "wmedian", "egger", "maxlik", "mbe", "conmix"),           snp_estimates = FALSE) mr_funnel(mr_input(bx = ldlc[1:8], bxse = ldlcse[1:8],             by = chdlodds[1:8], byse = chdloddsse[1:8])) mr_loo(MRInputObject) library(ggplot2) forest  = mr_forest(mr_input(ldlc, ldlcse, chdlodds, chdloddsse)) forest2 = forest + coord_cartesian(xlim=c(-5,5)) forest2

title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: multivariable method requires genetic associations multiple risk factors, different input function needed: mr_mvinput, creates MRMVInput object:
code: MVMRInputObject <- mr_mvinput(bx = cbind(ldlc, hdlc, trig),                               bxse = cbind(ldlcse, hdlcse, trigse),                               by = chdlodds,                                byse = chdloddsse)  MVMRInputObject ##     SNP exposure_1.beta exposure_2.beta exposure_3.beta exposure_1.se ## 1 snp_1           0.026           0.002           0.016         0.004 ## 2 snp_2          -0.044           0.005          -0.004         0.004 ## 3 snp_3          -0.038           0.003          -0.009         0.004 ##   exposure_2.se exposure_3.se outcome.beta outcome.se ## 1         0.004         0.008       0.0677     0.0286 ## 2         0.004         0.008      -0.1625     0.0300 ## 3         0.004         0.008      -0.1054     0.0310 ##  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 25 rows ] MVMRInputObject.cor <- mr_mvinput(bx = cbind(ldlc, hdlc, trig),                                   bxse = cbind(ldlcse, hdlcse, trigse),                                   by = chdlodds,                                    byse = chdloddsse,                                   correlation = diag(length(ldlc)))

title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: mr_mvivw command performs extension inverse-variance weighted method multivariable Mendelian randomization, implementing multivariable weighted linear regression (standard IVW method method performs univariable weighted linear regression) intercept term set zero. standard IVW method, correlation matrix can specified. Multivariable Mendelian randomization requires number genetic variants exceed number risk factors; case, method return error. Conditional F statistics: nx option specifies sample size(s) genetic associations exposures (either single value equal, vector differ). correl.x option specifies correlation genetic associations exposures. genetic assocations exposures estimates separate datasets, correlation matrix set identity matrix (default option). matrix calculated summarized data; unknown, sensitivity analysis value recommended. nx correl.x options used calculation estimates multivariable inverse-variance weighted method method, calculation conditional F statistics. Conditional F statistics relevant measure instrument strength multivariable Mendelian randomization. detail, see Sanderson, Spiller, Bowden (2021) “Testing correcting weak pleiotropic instruments two-sample multivariable Mendelian randomization”, doi: 10.1002/sim.9133. addition multivariable inverse-variance weighted method, several multivariable estimation methods available, generally multivariable extensions univariable methods: multivariable MR-Egger, multivariable median-based method, multivariable lasso method, multivariable constrained maximum likelihood, multivariable GMM, multivariable principal components GMM.
code: MVIVWObject <- mr_mvivw(MVMRInputObject,                           model = "default",                          correl = FALSE,                          correl.x = NULL,                          nx = NA,                          distribution = "normal",                          alpha = 0.05)  MVIVWObject <- mr_mvivw(MVMRInputObject)  MVIVWObject ##  ## Multivariable inverse-variance weighted method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##    Exposure Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value ##  exposure_1    1.925     0.439  1.064, 2.786   0.000 ##  exposure_2   -0.590     0.555 -1.677, 0.498   0.288 ##  exposure_3    0.723     0.230  0.272, 1.174   0.002 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  1.433  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 51.3599 on 25 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0014) MVIVWObject.condF <- mr_mvivw(MVMRInputObject, nx = 17723)  MVIVWObject.condF ##  ## Multivariable inverse-variance weighted method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##    Exposure Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value Cond F-stat ##  exposure_1    1.925     0.439  1.064, 2.786   0.000        20.3 ##  exposure_2   -0.590     0.555 -1.677, 0.498   0.288        12.9 ##  exposure_3    0.723     0.230  0.272, 1.174   0.002        13.3 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  1.433  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 51.3599 on 25 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0014)

title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: Multivariable MR-Egger extension MR-Egger method deal genetic variants associated multiple risk factors, introduced Rees et al (2017) “Extending MR-Egger method multivariable Mendelian randomization correct measured unmeasured pleiotropy” DOI: 10.1002/sim.7492 implement method using multivariable weighted linear regression. variants correlated, method implemented using generalized weighted linear regression; hard coded using matrix algebra. causal estimate obtained regression associations outcome associations risk factors, intercept estimated weights inverse-variances associations outcome.
code: MVEggerObject <- mr_mvegger(MVMRInputObject)  MVEggerObject ##  ## Multivariable MR-Egger method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Orientated to exposure : 1  ## Number of Variants : 28  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##     Exposure Estimate Std Error  95% CI        p-value ##   exposure_1    2.829     0.515  1.819,  3.839   0.000 ##   exposure_2   -0.663     0.496 -1.636,  0.310   0.182 ##   exposure_3    0.827     0.209  0.417,  1.237   0.000 ##  (intercept)   -0.028     0.010 -0.049, -0.008   0.007 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  1.280  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 39.3421 on 24 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0251)

title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: Multivariable median method similar univariable weighted median method, except implemented using quantile regression. implemented multivariable weighted quantile regression, quantile set 0.5 (median).

Multivariable MR-Lasso extends multivariable IVW model include intercept term genetic variant. intercept terms represent associations genetic variants outcome bypass risk factors. regularized regression model estimated multivariable weighted linear regression intercept terms subject lasso-type penalization. lasso penalization tend shrink intercept terms corresponding valid instruments zero. lasso penalty relies tuning parameter controls level sparsity. default use heterogeneity stopping rule, fixed value may specified. part analysis, genetic variants orientated associations one risk factors positive (first risk factor used default). Re-orientation genetic variants performed automatically part function. MR-Lasso method performed two steps. First, regularized regression model fitted, genetic variants identified valid instruments. Second, causal effects estimated using standard multivariable IVW valid genetic variants. post-lasso method performed long number genetic variants identified valid instruments greater number risk factors. default heterogeneity stopping rule always return genetic variants valid instruments risk factors identification. main estimates given method post-lasso estimates. title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: Multivariable MRcML (MVMRcML) extension MRcML deal multiple exposures, described Lin et al (2023) “Robust multivariable Mendelian randomization based constrained maximum likelihood” DOI 10.1016/j.ajhg.2023.02.014 . robust correlated uncorrelated pleiotropy univariable equivalent. practice, data perturbation (DP) version preferred practice robust inference can account uncertainty model selection. However, may take longer time especially number IVs large (range K_vec can large ). One strategy try small range K (number invalid IVs) first (small num_pert), adjust number selected invalid IVs fall close boundary. can also use methods, e.g. mr_mvlasso, get rough sense number invalid IVs. Similar mr_cML, multiple random starting points used find global minimum.
code: MVcMLObject <- mr_mvcML(MVMRInputObject, n = 17723)  MVcMLObject ##  ## Multivariable MRcML method  ##  ## Number of variants : 28  ## Results for:  MVMRcML-DP  ## Number of data perturbations with successful convergence:  200  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##    Exposure Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value ##  exposure_1    1.927     0.613  0.726, 3.127   0.002 ##  exposure_2   -0.350     0.671 -1.666, 0.966   0.602 ##  exposure_3    0.822     0.272  0.289, 1.354   0.002 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------

title: Multivariable Mendelian randomization
text: Multivariable Mendelian randomization via generalized method moments method described Hansen (1982) “Large sample properties generalized method moments estimators” DOI 10.2307/1912775 method accounts overdispersion heterogeneity genetic variant-outcome associations.
code: MVGMMObject <- mr_mvgmm(MVMRInputObject, nx=rep(17723,3), ny=17723)  MVGMMObject ##  ## Multivariable generalized method of moments (GMM) method ##  ## Exposure correlation matrix not specified. Exposures are assumed to be uncorrelated. ##  ## Robust model with overdispersion heterogeneity. ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##    Exposure Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value Cond F-stat ##  exposure_1    1.830     0.451  0.947, 2.713   0.000        20.3 ##  exposure_2   -0.722     0.580 -1.858, 0.415   0.213        12.9 ##  exposure_3    0.686     0.239  0.217, 1.155   0.004        13.3 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##  ## Overdispersion heterogeneity parameter estimate = 17.369  ##  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 24.9273

title: Univariable estimation methods
text: inverse-variance method equivalent standard instrumental variable method using individual-level data, two-stage least squares method. Either fixed- random-effects analysis can performed; “default” option fixed-effect analysis three variants fewer, random-effects analysis otherwise. robust option uses robust regression rather standard regression analysis, penalized option downweights contribution analysis genetic variants outlying (heterogeneous) variant-specific estimates. correlation matrix provided MRInput object, correlated method used default (correl = TRUE), robust penalized arguments ignored. default options constructing confidence intervals based normal distribution 95% confidence level, however one can use t-distribution (distribution = “t-dist”) alternative significance level desired. default option weights “simple”, corresponds inverse-variance weighted meta-analysis ratio estimates /bx using first-order standard errors byse/bx. Alternatively, weights can set “delta”, include second-order terms delta expansion. makes use psi, correlation variant association exposure outcome. mr_ivw function automatically calculates approximation first-stage F statistic regression exposure genetic variants. important measure instrument strength. correlation matrix specified, calculation estimated F statistic accounts correlation variants. correlation matrix specified, warning message appears remind user importance correct harmonization correlation matrix effect alleles genetic associations exposure outcome.

title: Univariable estimation methods
code: MRInputObject <- mr_input(bx = ldlc,                            bxse = ldlcse,                            by = chdlodds,                            byse = chdloddsse)  MRInputObject  # example with uncorrelated variants ##     SNP exposure.beta exposure.se outcome.beta outcome.se ## 1 snp_1         0.026       0.004       0.0677     0.0286 ## 2 snp_2        -0.044       0.004      -0.1625     0.0300 ## 3 snp_3        -0.038       0.004      -0.1054     0.0310 ## 4 snp_4        -0.023       0.003      -0.0619     0.0243 ## 5 snp_5        -0.017       0.003      -0.0834     0.0222 ## 6 snp_6        -0.031       0.006      -0.1278     0.0667 ##  [ reached 'max' / getOption("max.print") -- omitted 22 rows ] IVWObject <- mr_ivw(MRInputObject,                     model = "default",                     robust = FALSE,                     penalized = FALSE,                     correl = FALSE,                     weights = "simple",                     psi = 0,                     distribution = "normal",                     alpha = 0.05)  IVWObject <- mr_ivw(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse,    by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse))  IVWObject ##  ## Inverse-variance weighted method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##  Method Estimate Std Error 95% CI       p-value ##     IVW    2.834     0.530 1.796, 3.873   0.000 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  1.920  ## Heterogeneity test statistic (Cochran's Q) = 99.5304 on 27 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0000). I^2 = 72.9%.  ## F statistic = 28.0. title: Univariable estimation methods
text: median-based method calculates median variant-specific estimates ratio method genetic variant individually. default option calculate weighted median using inverse-variance weights. Alternatively, one can calculate simple (unweighted) median, weighted median using penalization weights heterogeneous variants. Since calculation standard error requires bootstrapping, number bootstrap iterations can varied. random seed set automatically results reproducible; however, value seed can changed required. function completed, random seed reset previous value (true functions package). median-based method requires data least 3 genetic variants. Variants must uncorrelated.
code: WeightedMedianObject <- mr_median(MRInputObject,                                    weighting = "weighted",                                    distribution = "normal",                                    alpha = 0.05,                                    iterations = 10000,                                    seed = 314159265)  WeightedMedianObject <- mr_median(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse,   by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse))  WeightedMedianObject ##  ##  Weighted median method  ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##                  Method Estimate Std Error 95% CI       p-value ##  Weighted median method    2.683     0.419 1.862, 3.504   0.000 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ SimpleMedianObject <- mr_median(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse,   by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse), weighting = "simple")  SimpleMedianObject ##  ##  Simple median method  ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##                Method Estimate Std Error 95% CI       p-value ##  Simple median method    1.755     0.740 0.305, 3.205   0.018 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------

title: Univariable estimation methods
text: MR-Egger method implemented using random-effects model . robust penalized options inverse-variance weighted method. method can used correlated uncorrelated sets variants. Confidence intervals can constructed either using normal distribution (distribution = “normal”, default option), t-distribution (distribution = “t-dist”). t-distribution, case -dispersion (estimated residual standard error regression model less 1), confidence intervals p-values use either t-distribution correction -dispersion, normal distribution residual standard error set 1 – whichever wider. means -dispersion doubly penalized setting residual standard error 1 using t-distribution, also confidence intervals narrower (p-values extreme) using fixed-effect model. MR-Egger method requires data least 3 genetic variants. Variants permitted correlated.
code: EggerObject <- mr_egger(MRInputObject,                          robust = FALSE,                         penalized = FALSE,                         correl = FALSE,                         distribution = "normal",                         alpha = 0.05)  EggerObject <- mr_egger(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse,   by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse))  EggerObject ##  ## MR-Egger method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants =  28  ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##       Method Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value ##     MR-Egger    3.253     0.770  1.743, 4.762   0.000 ##  (intercept)   -0.011     0.015 -0.041, 0.018   0.451 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual Standard Error :  1.935  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 97.3975 on 26 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0000) ## I^2_GX statistic: 91.9% EggerObject.corr <- mr_egger(MRInputObject.cor,                          correl = TRUE,                         distribution = "normal",                         alpha = 0.05)  EggerObject.corr <- mr_egger(mr_input(bx = calcium, bxse = calciumse,   by = fastgluc, byse = fastglucse, corr = calc.rho))  EggerObject.corr ##  ## MR-Egger method ## (variants correlated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants =  6  ##  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##       Method Estimate Std Error  95% CI       p-value ##     MR-Egger    1.302     1.518 -1.672, 4.276   0.391 ##  (intercept)    0.009     0.013 -0.017, 0.035   0.493 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual Standard Error :  0.629  ## Residual standard error is set to 1 in calculation of confidence interval when its estimate is less than 1. ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 1.5825 on 4 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.8119)

code: MaxLikObject <- mr_maxlik(MRInputObject,                            model = "default",                           correl = FALSE,                           psi = 0,                           distribution = "normal",                           alpha = 0.05)  MaxLikObject <- mr_maxlik(mr_input(bx = ldlc, bxse = ldlcse,   by = chdlodds, byse = chdloddsse))  MaxLikObject ##  ## Maximum-likelihood method ## (variants uncorrelated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants : 28  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##  Method Estimate Std Error 95% CI       p-value ##  MaxLik    3.225     0.569 2.110, 4.340   0.000 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  1.793  ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 86.8145 on 27 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.0000) MaxLikObject.corr <- mr_maxlik(mr_input(bx = calcium, bxse = calciumse,   by = fastgluc, byse = fastglucse, corr = calc.rho))  MaxLikObject.corr ##  ## Maximum-likelihood method ## (variants correlated, random-effect model) ##  ## Number of Variants : 6  ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ##  Method Estimate Std Error 95% CI       p-value ##  MaxLik    2.303     0.709 0.914, 3.692   0.001 ## ------------------------------------------------------------------ ## Residual standard error =  0.588  ## Residual standard error is set to 1 in calculation of confidence interval when its estimate is less than 1. ## Heterogeneity test statistic = 1.7277 on 5 degrees of freedom, (p-value = 0.8854)

title: MR-Egger method — mr_egger

title: Median-based method — mr_median
text: median-based methods greater robustness individual genetic variants strongly outlying causal estimates compared inverse-variance weighted MR-Egger methods. Formally, simple median method gives consistent estimate causal effect least 50% genetic variants valid instrumental variables (weighted median method, 50% weight comes valid instrumental variables). weighting "simple", estimate obtained calculating ratio causal estimates genetic variants theta = betaY/betaX, finding median estimate. weighting "weighted", estimate obtained : Calculating ratio causal estimates ordering genetic variants according magnitude estimates, .e. $$\theta_1 < \theta_2 < ... < \theta_J$$ Calculate normalized inverse-variance weights genetic variant \(w_1, w_2, ..., w_J\), :    $$w_j = \frac{\beta_{Xj}^2}{se(\beta_{Yj})^2} / \sum_{=1}^{J} \frac{\beta_{Xi}^2}{se(\beta_{Yi})^2}$$ Find k    $$s_k = \sum_{= 1}^k w_i < 0.5$$       $$s_{k+1}  = \sum_{= 1}^{k+1} w_i > 0.5$$ Calculate weighted median estimate extrapolation :    $$\theta_{WM} = \theta_k + (\theta_{k+1} - \theta_k) \times \frac{0.5 - s_k}{s_{k+1} - s_k}$$ simple median estimate weighted median estimate weights equal. Standard errors simple weighted median methods calculated bootstrapping. weighting "penalized", weighted method used, contribution genetic variants outlying (heterogeneous) ratio estimates analysis downweighted.

title: Draw a scatter plot of the genetic associations and/or causal estimates — mr_plot
text: object MRInput object MRMVInput object MRAll object. error viewing MRInput MRMVInput object, one can choose whether include error bars (default include). MRMVInput object, horizontal error bars take account uncertainty causal estimates. line viewing MRInput object, one can choose whether include IVW estimate (line = "ivw") MR-Egger estimate (line = "egger"). viewing MRMVInput, one can choose whether include line origin gradient 1 (line = TRUE) . orientate viewing MRInput MRMVInput object, one can choose whether orientate genetic variants associations risk factor positive. recommended particularly plotting MR-Egger estimate, although default setting FALSE. interactive viewing MRInput MRMVInput object, one can choose whether produce interactive graph using plotly package, static graph using regular plot command. labels viewing MRInput MRMVInput object interactive set FALSE, setting labels TRUE means name genetic variants appears corresponding datapoint.

title: Draw a scatter plot of the genetic associations and/or causal estimates — mr_plot
text: result dependent type object passed mr_plot. object MRInput object, function uses either plot command (interactive set FALSE) plotly syntax (interactive set TRUE) plot association estimates . object MRMVInput object, functionality similar except plot estimated associations outcome y-axis, fitted values associations outcome inverse-variance weighted method x-axis. interactive set FALSE, static graph produced. setting labels TRUE, names genetic variants appear points. produces less visually appealing graph, one easier identify individual genetic variants. interactive set TRUE, plot interactive user can hover various points see name associated genetic variant association estimates. object MRAll object, function generates ggplot compare causal estimates proposed different methods.

what: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
text: function pheno_input extracts summarized data associations named exposure outcome variables PhenoScanner.

title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
code: pheno_input(   snps,   exposure,   pmidE,   ancestryE,   outcome,   pmidO,   ancestryO,   correl = NULL )

title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
text: snps names (rsid) genetic variants included analysis. exposure name exposure variable. pmidE PubMed ID (PMID) publication genetic association estimates exposure originally reported. variables reported multiple consortia (example, associations coronary artery disease CARDIoGRAM 2011 [PMID:21378990], CARDIoGRAMplusC4D 2013, CARDIoGRAMplusC4D 2015 [PMID:26343387]). Equally, publications reported associations multiple variables (example, CARDIoGRAMplusC4D 2015 [PMID:26343387] reported associations coronary artery disease myocardial infarction). providing variable name PubMed ID, set associations (almost) uniquely identified. ancestryE ancestry individuals estimates obtained. small number studies reported genetic association estimates single variable single publication multiple ethnicities (example, associations log(eGFR creatinine) CKD-Gen 2016 [PMID:26831199] reported Europeans Africans). combination exposure name, PubMed ID, ancestry uniquely defines set associations. Providing ancestry also reminds analysts additional complication conducting Mendelian randomization associations exposure outcome individuals different ancestry. association estimates obtained "European" "Mixed" populations, although obtained "African", "Asian", "Hispanic" populations. outcome name outcome variable. pmidO PubMed ID publication genetic association estimates outcome originally reported. ancestryO ancestry individuals genetic association estimates outcome obtained. correl correlations genetic variants. specified, genetic variants assumed uncorrelated. Note correlations reference correct variants, list genetic variants needs alphabetical order.

title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
text: output pheno_input function MRInput object can used directly estimation functions (mr_ivw) plotting function mr_plot. output contains: bx genetic associations exposure. bxse corresponding standard errors. genetic associations outcome. byse corresponding standard errors. correlation matrix genetic correlations specified user. exposure character string giving name exposure provided PhenoScanner database. outcome character string giving name outcome provided PhenoScanner database. snps vector character strings names genetic variants.

title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
text: PhenoScanner bioinformatic tool (http://phenoscanner.medschl.cam.ac.uk/) curated database publicly available results large-scale genetic association studies. Queries can made individual genetic variants (SNPs small indels), multiple variants single batch query. association estimates standard errors can used Mendelian randomization analyses. phenoscanner command included MendelianRandomization package permission James Staley. function also available standalone package github: https://github.com/phenoscanner/phenoscanner.

title: Extract summarized data from PhenoScanner — pheno_input
text: James R Staley, James Blackshow, Mihir Kamat, Steve Ellis, Prvaeen Surendran, Benjamin B Sun, Dirk S Paul, Daniel Freitag, Stephen Burgess, John Danesh, Robin Young, Adam S Butterworth. PhenoScanner: database human genotype--phenotype associations. Bioinformatics 2016. doi: 10.1093/bioinformatics/btw373.
